Education:  
Ph.D. (1987) ,  Université des Sciences et Techn iques de Lille, France .  
 major : Spectrochimie  
M.S. (1982) ,   Peking University, China .  
   major : Spectroscopy & Quantum Electronics  
B.S. (1975) ,   Shandong University, China .  
   major : Optics  
 
Professional Experiences : 
May1993  – present, Research Professor, Research Associate Professor, Senior 
Research Scientist, Research Scientist, and Research A ssociate , at 
Washington University in  St. Louis, Missouri, USA.  
Jan.1992  – April199 3, Research Associate , Lab oratoire des  Spectrochimie 
Infrarouge et Raman, and Laboratoire des  Dynamique des Interactions 
Moléculaires, Le Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, France.  
Sept.1975  – Jan.1992 , Associate Professor , Engineer, and Assistant Engineer, 
Chinese Academy of Geological Sciences, Ministry of Land and 
Resources, China .  
Since 2005 , Guest Professor  of Shandong Univer sity, China  
 
Scientific and Technical Expertise:  
Since 1975: Molecular and atomic spectroscopy and their geological applications;  
Since 1994: Laser Raman, FTIR, Vis -NearIR, LIBS spectroscopic instrumentations 
and environmental chambers for Mars, Moon, Venu s, asteroids surface 
explorations;  
Since 1994: Raman spectral features of Martian, lunar, and extraterrestrial materials, 
their thermodynamics and kinetics properties;  
Since 2006: Thermodynamics and kinetics properties  of Mars relevant hydrous -
anhydrous sulfates, chlorides, and oxychlorides;  
Since 2008: Field investigations at Mars analogue sites (Atacama, Tibet, Arctic) on 
surface/subsurface mineralogy, salt precipitation sequences, and 
biomarkers;  
Since 2014 : Heterogeneous electrochemical reactions  in planetary atmosphere and in  
planetary  atmosphere -surface intera ction;

RESEARCH INTERESTS  
My research focuses on modeling and interpreting large -scale complex graphs. My lab is developing integrative and interpretable Graph 
AI models, graph representation learning, generating large -scale text -numeric graph datasets, building graph foundation models  and 
joint graph -text (LLMs)  models for  reliable and reproducible graph understanding and reasoning. Our long-term goal is to develop graph 
foundation models and AI agents to automate the understanding and reasoning of large -scale text -numeric graphs in real -world systems, 
thereby accelerating scientific discovery in a scalable, robust, and trustworthy manner. The a pplications focus on AI for precision health 
and precision medicine (AI4PHM), which represent some of the most challenging, fun damental, and impactful problems in AI research 
aimed at curing lethal and painful diseases.

 SELECTED RESEARCH FUNDING  
 
• 1R01LM013902 -01A1, NLM, 05/16/2023 – 02/29/2027,  ~$1.4 million  
Role: Principal Investigator (PI)  
“Modeling and targeting tumor -immune signaling interactions in tumor microenvironment.”  
In this study, my lab  develop s novel  integrative and interpretable  graphAI and joint graph -language  model ing for mining key graph 
node s and signaling flow s on large and complex graphs . These models are applied  to analyze large -scale single -cell omic data , 
uncover key cell -type-specific signaling targets  and modules, tumor -immune cell signaling interactions, and predict  effective  drugs 
perturbing the signaling systems to improve cancer patient s’ drug response an d outcomes . 
 
• 1RM1 NS132962 -01, NINDS Interdisciplinary Team Science  RM1  (equals to multiple R01s) , 07/2023 – 06/2028, ~ $7.9 million  
Role: multi -PI  
“Systems -Level Approach to Neuronopathic Lysosomal Storage Disorders.”  
In this study, my lab develop s novel computational  network -based  computational models, graph AI, and joint graph -text (LLM) AI 
models  to mine and build a knowledge graph of lysosome signaling system, and to integrate and interpret multi -omic data to uncover 
the key molecular targets and modules in the lysosome signaling graph  in neuronopathic lysosomal storage disorder diseases.  
 
• 1R21AG078799 - 01A1, R21/R33, NIA : Phase1: 07 /2023 -06/2025; Expected Phase2: 07 /2025 -06/2028, ~1.3 2 million  
Role: PI  
“AI models of multi -omic data integration for mining longevity core signaling pathways.”  
My lab collects and generate s large -scale text -numeric omic graphs and develop s novel interpretable graphAI  and joint graph -text 
models,  graph foundation models for reliable and  reproducible understanding  and reasoning on the  large -scale  graphs , to uncover key 
biomarkers and therapeutic targets  of longevity using  existing massive  multi -omic datasets generated from the  large -scale AD and  
longevity studies , like the following Long Life Family Study (LLFS ) project .  
 
• 5U19AG063893  Renewal (PI: Province) , 2025 ~ 2030, (Received a good score and have a good chance to be funded in this round 
or resubmission) .  
Role: Co-Investigator (Co -I), “The Long Life Family Study”  (LLFS)  
In the renewal of this large multi -center longevity project, my lab  will further develop novel integrative and interpretable Graph AI and 
joint graph -language  model ing to mine key graph entities and graph modules  associated with phenotypic changes  overtime , and apply 
these models to  systematically  analyze new LLFS generated large -scale longitudinal multi -omic datasets  with additional modalities  to 
identify key protectiv e biomarkers linked to to healthy and long life . (The total budget for my lab is ~1 million).  
 
• 1U19AI181984 -01; NIAID; 9/11/2024 – 8/31/2027  
Role: Co-Investigator  
“Vaccines and Therapeutic Antibodies to Respiro, Rubula, Peribunya and Phenuiviridae (R2P2) -ReVAMPP”  
A new  big p andemic preparedness research center  was awarded to study infectious -virus -vaccine -immunity  for “Research and 
Development of Vaccines and Monoc lonal Antibodies for Pandemic Preparedness (ReVAMPP) . My lab  work s on the data integration, 
and analysis of diverse  and heterogeneous  datasets via effective computational and novel AI models ( The total budget for m y lab is  
20% of my efforts ). 
 
• 1R56AG065352 -01A1, NIA , 09/15/2020 ~ 05/31/202 5 (in No-cost-extension (NCE)) , ~$1 million .                                                                             
Role: PI  
“Combine Genomics and Symptoms Data Driven Models to Discover Synergistic Combi natory Therapies for Alzheimer's Disease .” 
My lab develop s novel network -based computational and graph AI models for analyzing large and complex omic signaling graphs to 
mine  key signaling targets and predict drugs and synergistic drug cocktails  for AD prevention and treatment.  
 
• M-II-2019 -802, Children’s Discovery Institute,  2/1/19 -1/31/2 4 (NCE) , $375,000       
Role: PI                               
“Integrative Pharmaco -Genomics Model to Discover Synergistic Combinations for Groups 3/4 Pediatric Medulloblastoma  (MB) ”  
My lab develop s integrative and interpretable network -based computational and graphAI models  to uncover disease signaling nodes, 
and mining the signaling patterns of synergistic drug combinations , and apply the models to uncover the disease targets and predict 
synergistic drug combination s for MB cancer.   
 
• R01HL149853 (PI: Wambach) , NIH,  09/01/19 -08/31/ 24        
Role: Co -Investigator  
3 
 “Functional Characterization of ABCA3 Genomic Variants ” 
The goal  of this project is t o identify ABCA3 variants that disrupt intracellular trafficking using human pulmonary epithelial(A549) 
cell lines that stably express individual, disease -associated ABCA3 variants , and  to characterize ABCA3 mistrafficking variants that 
activate cellular stress and degradation pathways; and to identify FDA -approved compounds that rescue ABCA3 variant -encoded 
mistrafficking andnormalize mutant -activated cellular stress and degradation pathways . The automated quantitative image analysis of 
large -scale high content cellular images  is used to discover changes of image patterns and identify effective drugs .  
 
• U01DK100017 (PI: Lai ), NIH/ NIDDK, 07/2013 - 08/202 4 
Role: Co -Investigator  
“Symptoms of Lower Urinary Tract Dysfunction Research Network (LURN) Second Phase Study”  
The goal of this project is t o improve the care of patients who suffer from lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) by  understanding of 
LUTS phenotypes and underlying mechanisms behind the patient subtypes.  The patient -phenotype graph analysis models are 
developed to predict drug response, and identify the associated disease phenotypes of responders.  
 
Other /submi tted applications  
• 1R01DK139531 -01A1, NIDDK, 07/2025 - 06/2030 (Application Resubmission – Status: Submitted) ; ~3 million  
Role: Multi -PI 
“Dynamic cellular and molecular communication in metabolic dysfunction -associated fatty liver disease ” 
In the study, my lab will develop integrative and explainable  Graph AI and graph -language AI models for longitudinal  graph  analysis 
to identify key graph nodes  and graph signaling evolution  overtime ; and apply these models to identify the initiation and evolution of 
disease signaling at different stages of Non -alcoholic Steatohepatitis (NASH).

projects (3 NSF and 11 DOE) focus on the development of advanced materials for 
electrochemical energy conversion and storages such as fuel cells, water splitting, batteries, 
and renewable fuel (NH 3).  
 More than 180 scientific publications including Science, Nature Catalysis, JACS, Angew

139); 6 patents; 9 invited book chapters, 80 invited presentations ;

catalysts , especially the platinum group metal (PGM) -free catalysts. It is evident by his Science 
paper published in 2011 (Wu G et al., Science, 332, 443, 2011; cited > 2400 times to date in 
Google Scholar ), in which, for the first time, feasible catalysts from earth abundant element s

Description : This proposal aims to develop an effective neuroprotective treatment for

provide important preclinical evidence for a new class of disease -modifying treatment for  
Huntington’s disease and potentially for other ne urological disorders in which aberrant DNA  
methylation is implicated, and thus this research is relevant to public health.

RESEARCH PROGRAM  
The mission of the Chen Ultrasound  Laboratory is to advance the emerging field  of Neuro Sonics  
by integrating breakthroughs in neuroscience and ultrasonics . We aim to develop  noninvasive, 
precise ultrasound technologies to enhance  our understanding of brain function and transform the 
diagnosis and treatment of neurological diseases . My research program is structured around three 
core areas:  
• Sono -neuroscience : Using ultrasound as a noninvasive tool to investigate and discover 
intact brain function.  
• Sono -neuroengineering : Designing and developing advanced ultrasound -brain interface 
devices and technologies.   
• Sono -neuromedicine : Translating noninvasive ultrasound technologies into impactful 
clinical applications.

R01 HL9083901  PI: Shannon, William D  4/1/2009 -3/31/2012  
NIH 
New Data Analysis Methods for Actigraphy in Sleep Medicine  
The purpose of this study to develop statistic and informatics tolls for analyzing and 
visualizing actigraphy data linked to fatigue in sleep medicine center patients. An 
actigraph is a watch -like device attached to the wrist t hat uses an accelerometer to 
measure movement nearly continuously over several days. An American Academy of 
 4
 Sleep Medicine 2002 report defines the practice parameters for the use of actigraphy as a 
useful tool for detecting sleep in healthy individuals, as sessing specific aspects in 
insomnia and restless leg syndrome, and a useful adjunct to a detailed history and 
subjective sleep diary for diagnosing and treating insomnia, circadian -rhythm disorders, 
and excessive sleepiness. Concurrent with these recommen dations is an increased interest 
in the use of actigraphy as a tool for objectively measuring fatigue. With improved high -
end statistical methods for analyzing this data, actigraphy has the potential to become 
more important as an objective diagnostic tool  for determining fatigue, sleep 
abnormalities and assessing response to treatment. Other special areas of neurology and 
medicine where actigraphy can be used more effectively include restless leg syndrome, 
the elderly and nursing home patients with and wit hout dementia, newborns, infants, 
children, and adolescents, hypertensive individuals, depressed or schizophrenic patients, 
and individuals in in accessible situations.

Research support : 
Past 
2016 - 2017  Developing humanized mouse models for the study of HIV -1 latency and viral 
eradication. 
NIH/NIAID K99AI125065 
Role: Principal Investigator 
This proposal aims to develop a humanized mouse model to investigate HIV -1 latent infection 
in vivo and explore new strategies to design therapeutic vaccines to purge the latent viral 
reservoir.  
2017 - 2019  Developing humanized mouse models for the study of HIV -1 latency and viral 
eradication. 
NIH/NIAID R00AI125065 Role: Principal Investigator 
This proposal aims to develop a humanized mouse model to investigate HIV -1 latent infection 
in vivo and explore new strategies to design therapeutic vaccines to purge the latent viral 
reservoir.  
2018 - 2020  In vitro and in vivo analysis of macrophage -mediated clearance of HIV -1 latent 
reservoir.  
NIH/NIAID R21AI143413 Role: Principal Investigator 
This proposal aims to test CD47/SIRPα signaling blockade strategy to enhance antibody-
dependent phagocytosis of the latent viral reservoirs.  
Curriculum  Vitae                                 Liang Shan,  PhD 
 
 
 3 2019 - 2021  Role of dysbiotic  commensal bacteria in modulating airway inflammation in a mouse 
model with human lung immune system . 
NIH/NIAID R21AI139649 (Contact PI: Wang, Leyao ) 
Role: Co -principal Investigator  
This proposal aims to use humanized mouse models to discover how human airway 
microbiota modulates inflammatory response in the airways.  
2020 - 2022  A novel PCR -based method for quantification of antibody -dependent clearance of HIV -
1 reservoirs.  
NIH/NIAID R21AI150418 (PI: Liang Shan) 
Role: Principal Investigator 
This proposal aims to develop a PCR -based assay to quantify HIV envelop production. This 
assay can be used to monitor and predict antibody efficacy in clearing residual HIV reservoirs.  
2021 - 2024  A humanized mouse model for vaginal HIV -1 transmission.   
NIH/NIAID R21AI162262 (PI: Liang Shan) Role: Principal Investigator 
This proposal aims to use humanized mouse models to study vaginal HIV transmission and 
mucosal immune response.  
Active  
2020 - 2025 Novel strategies to enhance effector cell functions for antibody -mediated clearance of 
HIV -1 infection.   
NIH/NIAID R01AI155162 (PI: Liang Shan)  
Role: Principal Investigator 
This proposal aims  to develop novel strategies to enhance antibody- mediated cell -killing 
functions. Our study will improve antibody therapeutic efficacy in order to achieve a 
functional cure of HIV . 
2021 - 2026  Understand the role of CARD8 inflammasome in HIV -1 infection.   
NIH/NIAID R01AI162203 (PI: Liang Shan)  
Role: Principal Investigator 
This proposal aims to study the role of CARD8 inflammasome in HIV -1 infection and 
develop strategies to induce CARD8 activation to eliminate latent HIV -1 reservoirs  
2021 - 2026  CRISPR for Cure  Martin Delaney Collaboratories . 
NIH/NIAID UM1AI164568 (PI: Khalili Kamel & Tricia Burdo)  
Role: Co -investigator and research focus 2 co -leader.  
We aim to develop a  highly effective, genetic strategy involving gene editing to excise 
viral DNA from the host together in concert with immune cell activation/improvement . 
2023 – 2028  
 Harnessing the CARD8 Inflammasome for HIV Reservoir Elimination.   
NIH/NIAID R01AI176594 (PI: Liang Shan)  
Role: Principal Investigator 
This project seeks to understand whether the CARD8- inflammasome can be harnessed to 
eliminate infected cells, which may lead to control of HIV -1 without the requirement for 
lifelong treatment.  
2024 – 2029  
 Midwest Developmental Center for AIDS Research (D -CFAR).  
NIH P30 AI176532 (PI: Elvin Geng , Juliet Iwelunmor)  
Role: Director, Advance Technology Core 
This project aims to 1) a ttract, advance, and retain HIV investigators to accelerate the 
scientific response to HIV regionally and globally ; 2) d evelop and deploy institutional 
resources to promote interdisciplinary, innovative research for an effective and equitable 
HIV response ; 3) f oster engagement with communities and regional public health agencies 
to ensure stakeholder -responsive research and rapid utilization of findings into practice ; 4) 
Curriculum  Vitae                                 Liang Shan,  PhD 
 
 
 4 undertake an iterative evaluation of D -CFAR using both short -term process evaluation 
(using rapid- cycle methods) and longer -term impact assessment (using the Translational 
Sciences Benefits Model) to prepare for a full CFAR application.  
2024 – 2029  HIV Basic Science and Cure Research Training for Scientists at the University of 
Ghana.  
NIH D43TW012774  (PI: George Kyei, Liang Shan, Evelyn Yayra Afua Bonney)  
Role: Co -principal Investigator  
This D43 training program is a collaboration between two institutions (Washington 
University in St. Louis and the University of Ghana) to develop a comprehensive basic 
science research training program to prepare the next generation of Ghanaian researchers 
to conduct high quality HIV ba sic science and cure research.  
2024 – 2026  HIV -induced microbial alterations and inflammation in the lung of humanized mice . 
NIH/NIAID R21AI181675 (PI: Liang Shan and Leyao Wang) 
Role: Principal Investigator 
This grant will use an advanced humanized mouse model to better understand HIV -driven 
lung inflammation and microbial changes and promote mechanical studies to develop 
better procedures for screening, preventing, and treating lung diseases in people living with 
HIV.

Software Development  - R package ORIClust, http://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/ORIClust/ Co-developer: Tianqing Liu and Baoxue Zhang  ORIClust is a user-friendly R-based software package for gene clustering. Clusters are given by genes matched to pre-specified profiles across various ordered treatment groups. It is particularly useful for analyzing data obtained from short time-course or dose-response microarray experiments.  - R package methylMnM, http://epigenome.wustl.edu/MnM/ Co-developer: Yan Zhou, Bo Zhang, Baoxue Zhang, and Ting Wang  methylMnM  is an R package for joint analysis of methylated DNA immunoprecipitation (MeDIP) experiments [Weber et al., 2005] followed by sequencing (MeDIP-seq) and methyl-sensitive restriction enzymes experiments for unmethylated CpGs (MRE-seq).  R: 2+ years experience with Statistical modeling, Data mining and manipulating, High Dimensional Data 
Visualization, Machine Learning and Deep Learning implementations in R.  
 Statistical modeling and D ata analysis : Regression  model , ANOVA, MANOVA, GLM, GLMM, Time Series 
analysis, Spatial Analysis , Multivariate Model  and Machine Learning . 
 Solid background in Physics , Biotechnology and Statistics . 
 Proficiency in processing large -scale  complex data . 
 Machine Learning : Supervised Learning (Decision Tree, Neural Networks, Ridge/Lasso Regression, SVM, 
Random Forest, …), Unsupervised Learning (Clustering, PCA , …) 
 Deep Learning : Optimization Method, Nonlinear Dimensionality R eduction , Backpropagation algorithm, 
Restricted Boltzmann Machine, Aut oencoder Neural Network,…  
 Coding : Familiarity with various programing languages, C, perl, SQL, SQLPlus, python, java.  
 E xcellent c ommunication skills : providing statistical consultant services to non -statistic lab researcher  in the 
scientific research and d ata analysis in University of Missouri -Columbia.  
PROJECTS  
 I have abundant experience of  data analysis in  very broad range  with various machine/statistics learning techniques:   
1. Iowa State Corn  yield forecast model  with PCA dimension reduction and Random Forest  algorithm.   
    Use the historical Precipitation, Temperature and Sea Surface Temperature  (SST)  data to predict the annual corn 
yield of 9 Iowa Crop Reporting Districts (CRDs) through 1950 to 2015. The data is with very high dimensionalities 
and lar ge volumes  (96 locations in 714 month data for Precipitation and Temperature data; 2683 locations in 714 
months for the SST data) . The PCA technique  is applied to reduce the data dimension ality.  
    To evaluate the objective performance of the predictive model, a novel 10 -year running sampling framework is 
established. For the prediction of each year, only the previous 10 years data is applied in the training data set. The 
performances of models are evaluated through all past 50 years. After deliberate com parison and analysis of various 
statistical methods, the Random Forest model achieved best result. Except for a few years with extreme weather like 
1988 and 1993, the model exhibits very nice accuracy and strong reliability.  
2. Rossmann Pharmacy Sales pred ictions  with time series analy sis and Random Forest algorithm.  
    To predict the sales of Rossmann (one of the largest pharmacy store chain in Europe), the very large and complex 
data (including promotions, competition, school and state holidays seasonali ty and locality informat ion of 1115 
stores) are provided. After the data exploration and cleaning, a Random Forest model is established and achieved 
very high accuracy (Cross Validation MSE ~ 0.01 of sales amount under log scale). The factor importance ana lysis 
and outlier analysis furthermore suggested the extreme weather condition is the most potential influential factor.  
3. Prudential Life Insurance Assessment Analysis  with Ridge Regression method . 
    Prudential is one of the largest issuers of life ins urance in the USA. The model is built based on over a hundred 
variables describing attributes of life insurance applicants, from demographic, health condition, Medical record to 
insurance history, etc. To deal the high dimensional model, the Ridge Regressi on model is applied for the model 
selection. The model provides very nice accuracy.   
4. SpringLeaf Market Response predictions  with feature selections algorithm . 
    Using a large set of anonymous features of customer information to build the predictive model on the customer 
response. To deal with the data with very high dimensions (1932 features with 145232 customers), different model 
selection and dimension reduc tion techniques are applied.

OMB No. 0925-0001 and 0925-0002 (Rev. 10/2021 Approved Through 01/31/2026)  BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH Provide the following information for the Senior/key personnel and other significant contributors. Follow this format for each person. DO NOT EXCEED FIVE PAGES. NAME: Wang, Qian eRA COMMONS USER NAME (credential, e.g., agency login): QIAN_WANG POSITION TITLE: Assistant Professor EDUCATION/TRAINING (Begin with baccalaureate or other initial professional education, such as nursing, include postdoctoral training and residency training if applicable. Add/delete rows as necessary.)  INSTITUTION AND LOCATION DEGREE (if applicable) END DATE MM/YYYY FIELD OF STUDY Wuhan University, Wuhan BS 06/2009 Biology University of Alberta, Edmonton PHD 01/2016 Physiology Columbia University, New York Postdoctoral Fellow 05/2021 Ophthalmology A. Personal Statement I am an Assistant Professor of Ophthalmology and Visual Sciences at Washington University School of Medicine, starting from September 2024. I am highly motivated to pursue an academic career in vision science, especially in eye development and diseases. My PhD training in molecular biology and cell biology, together with my postdoctoral training in ophthalmology and mouse genetics, has equipped me with the skills to successfully conduct research in this field. I obtained my PhD degree in Physiology with Dr. Xing-Zhen Chen at University of Alberta. I studied the interactions of membrane proteins and the cytoskeleton network, using in vitro cell culture models. I identified novel binding partners of membrane proteins, including Transient Receptor Potential (TRP) channel TRPP2 and Epithelium Sodium Channel (ENaC), and further demonstrated the regulatory roles of cytoskeleton on channel function. This research provided me with extensive experience in strategies used in molecular biology and cell biology, which will be valuable for conducting mechanistic studies in my further research. When I joined Dr. Xin Zhang’s lab at Columbia University as a postdoctoral researcher, I began to study how Fibroblast Growth Factor (FGF) signaling regulates lens and lacrimal gland development. I received comprehensive training in mouse genetics and various aspects of eye development and diseases. My published work has provided insights into how FGF signalling is propagated1 and its role in lens development2, and has also elucidated the unique functions of FGF downstream cascades including mitogen activated protein kinase (MAPK)3, phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)4, and phospholipase Cg (PLCg)5 pathways, in lacrimal gland development.  With a solid background in studying signaling networks using mouse genetics, my long-term research goal is to explore the role of lipid signaling networks in eye development. As an initial step toward this goal, I propose to establish a mouse model to investigate the role of the lipid phosphatase OCRL, whose deficiency causes a genetic disorder with ocular manifestations in humans. Ongoing and recently completed projects that I would like to highlight include:  K99EY032171-01A Role: PI 06/2022-08/2028 Signaling networks and transcriptional programs in lens vesicle formation

Contribution to Science PhD career 
1. Discovery of the dynamics of membrane proteins and the cytoskeleton network. My PhD study was mainly focused on studying the structural and functional interactions of membrane proteins and the cytoskeleton network. 1) I have identified a cytoskeletal protein filamin-A as a novel binding partner of polycystin-2, the mutations of which account for ~15% of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). I further discovered a calcium-dependent regulatory mechanism of the polycystin-2 and filamin-A complex. These publications have contributed to the ADPKD field by suggesting a dynamic working model of polycystin-2 and the cytoskeletons. 2) I also systematically characterized the structural and functional interaction between the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) and filamin. This work suggests a link between ENaC and ADPKD through the cytoskeleton.  a. Wang Q, Dai XQ, Li Q, Wang Z, Cantero Mdel R, Li S, Shen J, Tu JC, Cantiello H, Chen XZ. Structural interaction and functional regulation of polycystin-2 by filamin. PLoS One. 2012;7(7):e40448. PubMed Central PMCID: PMC3393660.  b. Wang Q, Dai XQ, Li Q, Tuli J, Liang G, Li SS, Chen XZ. Filamin interacts with epithelial sodium channel and inhibits its channel function. J Biol Chem. 2013 Jan 4;288(1):264-73. PubMed Central PMCID: PMC3537021.  c. Wang Q, Zheng W, Wang Z, Yang J, Hussein S, Tang J, Chen XZ. Filamin-a increases the stability and plasma membrane expression of polycystin-2. PLoS One. 2015;10(4):e0123018. PubMed Central PMCID: PMC4393133.  2. Identification of Cis- and trans-regulatory mechanisms of the polycystic proteins. In collaboration with colleagues, we systematically studied the role of 5' and 3' untranslated regions (UTRs) of PKD2, which encodes polycystin-2, and found that both UTRs contain critical motifs that control polycystin-2 translation. This work elucidated the mechanisms underlying translational regulation of polycystin-2. We also identified polycystin-2L1 (also called TRPP3) as a novel regulatory target of the receptor for activated C kinase 1 (RACK1). The property of TRPP3 channel in response to calcium and acid was further characterized in the Xenopus oocyte model. This work elucidates the mechanisms of functional regulation of TRPP3 channel. a. PubMed PMID: 23985800.  Post-doctoral career 3. Dissecting the role of FGF downstream cascades in lacrimal gland development. My postdoctoral research is focused on how FGF downstream cascades regulate lacrimal gland development. 1) I showed that FGF induced PI3K signaling restricts EGF receptor expression from the lacrimal gland stalk to the bud region and demonstrated that this suppression of EGF signaling is necessary for the induction of lacrimal gland buds. 2) I found that Phospholipase Cγ regulates lacrimal gland branching by competing with PI3K in phosphoinositide metabolism. This work has been awarded the Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council of Canada (NSERC) postdoctoral fellowship in 2018-2020. 3) In collaboration with colleagues, we demonstrated the role of Etv (also called Pea3) transcription factors in lacrimal gland cell fate determination. We found that loss of Pea3 family genes biased the lacrimal gland epithelium toward an epidermal cell fate. This study resolves the long-standing conundrum of how FGF induces the lacrimal gland fate, providing directives for lacrimal gland regeneration for future treatment of dry eye diseases.

In collaboration with colleagues, 1) we investigated how FGF signaling is propagated through its adaptor protein complex. We found that Shc1 collaborates with Frs2 and Shp2 to target Grb2 in FGF signaling in lens development (accepted in Elife). 2) we studied the role of FGF downstream transcription factors Etv family members. We elucidated a functional divergence between FGF signaling and its downstream signal regulated transcription factors Etv genes in lens development.  a. Discovery of the signaling networks in lens vesicle formation. 1) In collaboration with colleagues, we found that Abelson kinase regulates FGF signaling to promote the tension-mediated lens vesicle separation (under revision in Science Advances). 2) I identified mTOR signaling as a novel regulator in lens vesicle separation process, and I am currently investigating the mechanisms of mTOR-mediated lens vesicle separation (K99/R00 proposal). This research will uncover the mTOR signaling networks during lens vesicle development, which is novel and significant in the field of lens development. a. Research Interests 
•Examine environmental influences and population-level interventions on weight-related
behaviors and outcomes throughout the life course.
•Assess socioeconomic determinants and policies that impact individuals’ dietary behavior,physical activity, sedentary lifestyle, and adiposity in children, adults of all ages, and people
with disabilities.
•Develop a well-rounded knowledge base and policy recommendations under the social-
ecological framework that can inform decision-making and social resource allocation in
combating the obesity epidemic.

• Brown School mask donation and delivery program, Founder, 2020. The program collected masks from Brown School’s Chinese community and delivered those masks to those most in need of personal and familial protection against the COVID-19 infection. The program 
delivered over 1,500 masks to approximately 150 students, faculty, and staff at Brown 
School, 2020 
• Brown School and Arts & Sciences panel discussions on COVID-19, 2020. I served as a panelist on two panel discussions, which aimed to disseminate COVID-19-related 
information and knowledge, address the audience’s questions and concerns, and solicit 
suggestions for designing and implementing policy countermeasures at the School/College and University level to mitigate the adverse impact of COVID-19 
• Brown School focus group studies on COVID-19, 2020. In collaboration with Linyun Fu, I 
conducted four focus group studies with a total of 50 Chinese students at Brown School. The 
focus group studies were conducted when COVID-19 broke out in Wuhan and started to spread to other places in China. The studies aimed to evaluate Chinese students’ concerns, challenges, potential discrimination and xenophobia experiences, and overall wellbeing under COVID-19; assess their needs; link those in need to resources at the School and University; inform policy countermeasures at the School and University level; and strengthen the sense of belonging and encourage leadership 
• Brown School Global Advisory Committee, Member, 2020 
• Brown School meta-analysis consultation services, Lead, 2019-2024. In collaboration with 
Brown School Library, I offered meta-analysis consultation services supplementary to the 
Library’s existing systematic review consultation services. The meta-analysis consultation services include: quantitative data extraction from the literature; effect size calculation and transformation; meta-analysis; meta-regression; and publication bias inspection, test, and correction

NARRATIVE  SECTION  
 
I have extensive expertise in virology, immunology, and gastroenterology. Over the past five years, 
my laboratory has established a strong track record of studying rotavirus -host interactions, SARS -
CoV-2 intestinal infection, and antiviral immunity at mucosal surfaces. My strategic vision for the next 
five years involves leveraging the rotavirus reverse genetics system, primary intestinal organoid 
cultures, and a neonatal mouse model to elucidate the molecular mechanisms underlying rotavirus 
host range restriction. I anticipate identifying the viral determinants and delineating the signaling 
pathway associated by which human and murine rotaviruses establish s uccessful infection in human 
and mouse intestinal epithelial cells, respectively. Additionally, I plan to tackle two outstanding 
questions in the rotavirus field: the identification of a yet -to-be-discovered proteinaceous receptor for 
human rotaviruses and  the improvement of suboptimal rotavirus vaccine efficacy in low -to-middle -
income countries. These ambitious projects, to be supported by NIH R01 grants, are poised to yield 
impactful insights into rotavirus replication, pathogenesis, and immunity. Further more, they will pave 
Siyuan Ding , Ph.D.  Curriculum Vitae     Page 13 the way for the rational design of improved next -generation vaccines and antiviral therapeutics 
against rotavirus, ultimately mitigating infection -associated morbidity and mortality. Finally, my plans 
extend to expanding my current res earch program beyond rotavirus and SARS -CoV-2 to include a 
third enteric virus, whether it be non -cultivable group B rotaviruses, human noroviruses, or 
echoviruses. I aspire for my laboratory to be internationally recognized for its exceptional training 
environment, rigorous scientific output, and substantial contributions to the understanding of enteric 
viral pathogenesis and antiviral innate immunity.

RESEARCH INTERESTS  
I aim to develop a synergistic research program focused, at the application level, on energy and 
environmental related challenges and, at the fundamental level, on rational and directed design of novel 
nanostructured materials by gas -phase synthesis approa ch. My research interests lie in t he synthesis of 
nanoparticles , the functionalization of fine particles, and the engineering of porosity, morphology, and 
microstructure of thin films based on synthesis, characterization, and applications. Gas -phase 
Atomic /Molecular Layer Deposition (ALD/MLD) in scalable fluidized bed reactors is used to carry out 
the synthesis of nanomaterials and particle surface functionalization for various applications (e.g., 
catalysis, energy storage, and environmental remediation).

PATENT S 
1. Yu, Y. Artificial antigen -presenting cells and methods for producing and using the same, PCT/ US 
10,556,016 B2  & PCT/US 11,833,218 B2 . 
Synopsis:  These two  approved patent s describe the development of biomimetic Janus particles 
as artificial antigen -presenting cells capable of activating T cells in vitro. T cells activated by the 
Janus particles can be employed in adoptive cellular immunotherapies for treating cancer and 
other diseases.  
 3.   Yi, Y.; Lee, S. ; Yu, Y. Multi -channel reporter particle and methods or making and using the same. 
PCT/US2022/076520 , claiming priority to US provisional application No. 63/245,646 (2021).  
Synopsis : This patent application describes the development of a multi -channel nanoparticle 
biosensor for the simultaneous detection of two or more chemical processes associated with 
pathogen degradation in cells. The nanoparticle biosensor has the potential to be  used for the early 
detection of infections and for screening therapeutic drugs for treating infections.   
4.    Yu, Y.; Wiemann, J. ; Bhattacharyya, S.  Antibiotic amphiphilic nanoparticle and methods of using 
the same against Gram -negative and/or Gram -positive bacteria. PCT/US2023/062203 , claiming 
priority to US provisional application No. 63/307,890 (2021).  
Synopsis : This patent application describes the development of Janus nanoparticles as a new 
antibacterial material. These nanoparticles effectively inhibit the growth of both Gram -negative and 
Gram -positive bacteria and can potentially be used as a broad -spectrum antibiotic on surfaces or 
to treat bacterial infections in patients.  
5.     Yu, Y.; Zhang, Z. Early sepsis detection through neutrophil swarming kinetics quantifications, US 
provisional application No. 18/637,635  (filed April 17, 2024).

RESEARCH INTEREST S 
• To understand the pathogenesis of  pulmonary arterial hypertension using novel animal models, 
integrated pharmacological approaches , genome editing and single cell RNA -sequencing.  
• To delineate the mechanisms of right heart failure in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension.  
• To identify therapeutic target s for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension patients.
